node.text:
A lot of you asked me to save this answer from my stories so I thought I’d make it into an IGTV post. I am answering one question everyday this month in honour of May being mental health awareness month. The question asked was: How can I be okay with my emotions and not feel overwhelmed by them? .

Also, in this video, I mention that we have the ability to control our emotions. But what I actually mean here is that we have the ability to control our *response* to our emotions. .

Hope some of you find this helpful ♥️ Take care, Nawal

node.title: How To Not Feel Overwhelmed by my Emotions

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology in San Francisco Bay Area. May be an image of text.

node.text:
We are all more than capable of seizing control of our life and our healing. Some of us may have to work harder than others, but we are all capable and deserving of creating a better future for ourselves. The faster we start to realize this, the sooner things will start to improve. Hold yourself accountable for your behaviors and habits that work against your overall wellbeing. Get uncomfortable and challenge yourself to do better and be better. Be disciplined, stay committed, and protect your energy by holding boundaries. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Self-reflection Prompt: Which one of these do you need to focus on more?

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️ 

*please see disclaimer on highlights

node.text:
Join me in my free workshop this Monday (July 19, 2021) where I discuss Instagram growth strategies that worked for my business - you can register using the link in my bio ✨

If you are a health professional with a practice and has not yet started an online social media presence…. What are you waiting for? 

Healthcare has been slow to adopt social media marketing but many professionals are beginning to understand the value of online marketing. 

I’m really excited about this workshop and look forward to seeing you live! When you sign up, be sure to check your spam/promotional folder for the registration email (sometimes the email gets sent there) ♥️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021 tagging @psychologiststephanie. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '@psychologiststephanie @thebraincoach How to Self- regulate By Understanding The Window of Tolerance Hyper- arousal When You Are Overwhelmed Window of Tolerance When You Feel Grounded Calm Hypo- arousel When You Become Numb From All Feeling'.

node.text:
When it comes to regulating our emotions, we need to first understand how our nervous system works (brain-body) especially under times of adversity or stress. One way to do this is by identifying our ‘Window of Tolerance’. 

The Window of Tolerance is a term coined by Dr. Dan Siegel. He suggests that we all have an optimal arousal level (i.e. the window of tolerance) in which we are able to keep our calm and regulate our feelings. When we experience uncomfortable emotions or difficult situations (such as pain, fear, anger, and trauma triggers), we get close to the edges and may get pushed into hyper-arousal or hypo-arousal states. When this happens, we want to try to get back into the Window of Tolerance. 

In this post, Dr. Stephanie @psychologiststephanie and I share with you what the Window of Tolerance is and what Hyper-arousal and Hypo-arousal states feel like. This is important to understand because it allows us to become aware of when we are in any of these states. Next, we share what we can do if we get pushed away from our Window of Tolerance. We hope you find this post to be informative and insightful! 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

*please see disclaimer in highlights.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021 tagging @psychologiststephanie. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '@psychologiststephanie @thebraincoach How to Self- regulate By Understanding The Window of Tolerance Hyper- arousal When You Are Overwhelmed Window of Tolerance When You Feel Grounded Calm Hypo- arousel When You Become Numb From All Feeling'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '@psychologiststephanie @thebraincoach What is the Window of Tolerance? Within the window of tolerance we're in a calm state, able to reflect, think rationally, make decisions and hold conversations, tolerating' the ups and downs of our emotions fear, anger, sadness, joy. Emotions become unbearable/ intolerable when we're out of this window.'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '@psychologiststephanie @thebraincoach The Window of Tolerance 'HyperArousal Zone' Sympathetic Nervous System Fight/ Flight response Feeling emotionally unsafe Emotional overwhelm/ reactivity Impulsivity •Overeating/ restricting/ addictions Anger/ Rage/ Defensiveness Racing/ Obsessive thoughts Poor judgment Feeling emotionally safe Being open & curious Ability self- regulate/ soothe Feel & think simultaneously Awareness of boundaries •Ability to feel empathy •Present moment awareness Access to intuition 'Window of Tolerance' Ventral Vagal Nerve Calm/ Collected/ Connected 'HypoArousal Zone' Parasympathetic Nervous System Freeze response •Feeling numb, no energy Inability to think clearly •Ashamed, Isolation •Can't defend oneself, say 'no' Collapse, Dissociation •Emptiness, Hopelessness Save as a Resource'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '@psychologiststephanie @thebraincoach Hyper- arousal state Wher we are too exhausted or sad our brain may shut down into survival mode.Fear may be triggered by unconscious thoughts, by a bodily feeling or by (perceived) abandonment/ rejection Being overwhelmed can vary from defensiveness up to rage.'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '@psychologiststephanie @thebraincoach state Hypo- arousal When we become too hyper- aroused, we might 'shut down' into a state of hypo- arousal. This can affect our sleep, appetite and digestion and may make us feel emotionally deadened, depressed, numb, disconnected, leading to dissociation or depersonalisation.'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '@psychologiststephanie @pschologistephanie@thebrainoach @thebraincoach Window of Tolerance & childhood trauma With childhood trauma/ emotion regulation problems, we tend to fall out of the window more quickly and might need more time to restore. The more safe and supported we feel, the less likely we will fall out of this window.'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'psychologiststephanie Othebraincoach How do we Self- regulate? Goal: Work towards reaching the Window of Tolerance' 'HyperArousal Zone' Too much arousal to integrate 'Cool down' 'Window of Tolerance' Optimal arousal zone 'HypoArousal Zone' Too little arousal to integrate Feeling calm ↑ 'Warm up''.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '@psychologiststephanie @thebraincoach If You Are in The 'HyperArousal Zone' Try this: Cool 'Cool down' Ground yourself focus on physical sensations Practice Mindfulness allow & observe your emotions without judging Self- soothe calm your body Practice Deep belly breathing Listen to Calming Music'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '@psychologiststephanie @thebraincoach If You Are in The 'HypoArousal Zone' Try this: ↑ 'Warm up' Stimulate your senses/ arousal Get out of your comfort zone Smell essential oils Move, dance'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '@psychologiststephanie @thebraincoach Was this post helpful? Save this post as a resource Follow: @thebraincoach @psychologiststephanie'.

Photo shared by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 13, 2021 tagging @mindovermoon. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '6 NEUROSCIENCE-BASED HABITS TO BOOST HAPPINESS ያ @mindovermoon @thebraincoach'.

node.text:
In this post, Tahura (@mindovermoon) and I discuss with you six habits backed by neuroscience to improve mood. 

These are small changes we can make in our lives to regulate stress levels, release serotonin, boost happiness, and reduce the risk of depression. 

Which one of these are you already doing? What are some habits you would like to focus on more? 

We hope you find this post helpful and that it inspires you to keep working on yourself. Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

*please see disclaimer in highlights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 13, 2021 tagging @mindovermoon. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '6 NEUROSCIENCE-BASED HABITS TO BOOST HAPPINESS ያ @mindovermoon @thebraincoach'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 13, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'NEUROSCIENCE RITUALS TO BOOST HAPPINESS 1. PRACTICE GRATITUDE Feeling grateful activates the brain stem region that produces dopamine + it can also boost serotonin. WHAT YOU CAN DO: Send text to friends family and show your appreciation Take pictures of things around you that you find beautiful Make list of all the things that make you happy and grateful @mindovermoon @thebraincoach'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 13, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'NEUROSCIENCE RITUALS TO BOOST HAPPINESS 2. SELF-AWARENESS Research shows that consciously recognizing your emotions reduces their impact on your thoughts and behaviors. Suppressing emotions can make you feel worse. WHAT YOU CAN DO: .Journal describe how you're feeling •Challenge unhelpful thoughts .Meditate or engage in short mindfulness activities F<<人 (Lieberman 2007) @mindovermoon @thebraincoach'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'NEUROSCIENCE RITUALS TO BOOST HAPPINESS 3. DECISION MAKING When you procrastinate making a decision, it can cause stress overwhelm. This affects the limbic system -part of brain responsible for behavioural & emotional responses. WHAT YOU CAN DO: Make list of pros & cons of each choice .Then, make a "good enough" decision instead of "perfect" one .Note: Trying to achieve perfection will only overwhelm you more! @mindovermoon @thebraincoach'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 13, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '6NEUROSCIENCE RITUALS TO BOOST HAPPINESS 4. SOCIAL CONTACT Humans are inherently social. We need a human touch and we need strong support network. Research shows that social exclusion activates the same circuitry as physical pain, whereas, touching someone you love actually reduces pain! WHAT YOU CAN DO: .Re-evlaute the people you surround yourself with do they bring value to your life? Are your values aligned? Do they make you feel good about yourself? Meet friends family in person •Hug your favourite person! (longer hugs release oxytocin, which reduces stress) (Sherman, Michikyan, Greenfield, 2013) @mindovermoon @thebraincoach'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 13, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '6NEUROSCIENCE RITUALS TO BOOST HAPPINESS 5. MEANINGFUL ACTIVITIES Research confirms that doing little things regularly is much better for happiness than doing one big thing once in while. Lots of little positive things allow you to rewire your brain and consciously change the way you perceive the world. WHAT YOU CAN DO: •Plan favourite activity for yourself each day e.g. skin care ritual, coffee shop, watch a movie etc •Engage in hobbies regularly or try out new activities e.g. yoga, hiking, art etc •Give back to the community through volunteer work (Dichtertal,2009) @mindovermoon @thebraincoach'.
Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 13, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text.
Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on July 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'If you found this helpful, please: for more, follow: @mindovermoon @thebraincoach'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology in Foster City, California. May be an image of flower and text that says 'Nawal Mustafa M.A. thebraincoach You are allowed to unlearn parts of you that do not align with who you are now You are allowed to re-evaluate your beliefs You are allowed to change your mind You are allowed to redefine your identity You are allowed to let go of behaviors and habits that hinder your growth'.

node.text:
Gentle reminder: You are allowed to unlearn parts of you that do not align with who you are now.

▪️You are allowed to re-evaluate your beliefs 
 
▪️You are allowed to change your mind

▪️You are allowed to redefine your identity

▪️You are allowed to let go of behaviors and habits that hinder your growth

Awareness leads to change. Change leads to self-growth. Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology in San Francisco Bay Area. May be an image of text that says 'How To Work Through Your Emotions Name the Emotion •Iam am feeling (Examples: Angry, Sad, Fearful, Worried) felt like (describe feeling in few words). Identify the Cause I was (where) remember noticing Identify the Behavior Challenge the Emotion •Was my (feeling) appropriate to the situation? Is this situationa distress that I can control? is out of my control, is this distress I have to accept and Nawal Mustafa; M.A. tolerate? When I felt I (behavior/action) What I wish I had done was thebraincoach'.

node.text:
Since we have been discussing emotion regulation in the last few posts, I wanted to share with you another helpful ‘tool’. One of the best ways to work through your emotions is by writing them down. If you can record how you are feeling and what you are thinking, you are better able to track your emotions and notice the triggers/warning signs. Putting down our problems on paper often helps us identify the cause and find a solution more clearly. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
This is my version of a “mood journal”. The questions in it prompt you to record your feelings and work through them. Once you start recording for several days or weeks, you will begin to notice patterns or trends. By recognizing these trends, you can work on eliminating or avoiding certain triggers. You do not have to use a physical paper and pencil for it, if it is more convenient for you, use an app on your phone (such as Notes). ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The last step is the most important. For situations you can change, make an action plan. For example, if your partner said something hurtful, have an honest conversation with them. Some situations, however, are out of our control. If that is the case, think of some coping mechanisms you can use to alleviate the feeling (such as spending time with friends, going for a short walk, or using breathing techniques.) ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Working on improving your emotional health does not mean you will find a solution to your triggers right away. This takes time and requires repeated practice.
Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

node.text:
Many of you requested I create more of these self-regulation cards, so I made another one with commonly experienced uncomfortable emotions. 

Take what you need❣️. I encourage you to save this post as a ‘tool-box’ for self-regulating. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ✨

node.text:
PSA from a clinical neuropsychology PhD candidate: Stop ignoring your emotions 🛑 

Emotions are signals from our brain and body that tell us what we need and when things are off-balance. 

Instead, ask yourself: What is this feeling trying to tell me? 

Sending you love, Nawal ♥️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology in San Francisco Bay Area. May be an image of text that says 'How to Self-Regulate Nawal Mustafa M.A. thebraincoach When am Feeling Stressed will Focus on what can control and let go of what cannot control Down Acknowledge my feelings and do something for myself that brings me joy Not Good Enough Remind myself of my strengths and take baby steps to improve my shortcomings Lonely Video call or meet with someone love and care about Anxious Focus on the present moment and take deep breaths to regulate my nervous system'.

Take what you need 🥰. I encourage you to save this post as a ‘tool-box’ for self-regulating. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal 💕

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on June 30, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Nawal Mustafa; M.A. thebraincoach 10 Signs of Emotional Exhaustion to Look Out For References: Wright and Croponzano (1998); Maslach and Jackson (1986)'.

node.text:
Research shows that emotional exhaustion is one of the three interrelated components that lead to burnout (Maslach & Jackson, 1986). According to this 3-component conceptualization, the other two factors are depersonalization and diminished accomplishment. If you are feeling emotionally exhausted, allow yourself some time to rest (seriously). Overworking or extending ourselves beyond our limits can only get us so far for so long. Listen to your body when it needs rest and check in often on how you are feeling. This is a preventative measure for burnout and ensures you are actively working on yourself to not get to a point of emotional exhaustion. 

I can personally resonate with a few of these signs right now. Moving across country and settling in has been time consuming and tiring. Plus, I am still working full time so the workload and tasks feel overbearing. I think this post serves as a reminder to me and hopefully to those of you feeling similarly to consciously take some time to rest and recuperate, whatever that looks like for you 🤍

Note: I encourage you to use the information I share on here as a guide. Everyone’s experience is unique so some strategies/tools might not be relevant to your specific situation. Please see disclaimer in my highlights. Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ✨

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on June 30, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Nawal Mustafa; M.A. thebraincoach 10 Signs of Emotional Exhaustion to Look Out For References: Wright and Croponzano (1998); Maslach and Jackson (1986)'.

Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on June 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Nawal Mustafa; M.A thebraincoach 10 Signs of Emotional Exhaustion to Look Out For 1.You don't feel fulfilled with your work and/or relationships anymore 2. Everything you do feels forced and you often feel tired 3. You find yourself withdrawing from people or pushing them away You feel fatigued when you get up in the morning and have to face another day of the same routine/workload 5. You often struggle with regulating your emotions which predominantly tend to be irritability, anxiety, or feeling overwhelmed References: Wright and Croponzano and Jackson(1986) ackson'.
Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on June 30, 2021. May be an image of text.
Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology in Foster City, California with @psychologiststephanie. May be an image of one or more people and text.

node.text:
In this post, I collaborated with Dr. Stephanie Carinia (clinical psychologist - @psychologiststephanie ) to discuss the various stages of arousal we experience.

The “Window of Tolerance” is the zone of arousal in which we are able to function most optimally. This is when one is calm, collected, and connected to their surroundings. 

When we are in our window of tolerance, our brain is functioning at its best and can process stimuli effectively. This results in us being able to adequately self-regulate, think clearly, and make rational decisions. 

On the other hand, when we are under extreme stress, we either experience a hyper-arousal state or a hypo-arousal state. Hyper-arousal is our fight/flight response that exacerbates feelings of anxiety and panic and leads to hyper-vigilance. Hypo-arousal state is our freeze response which can result in us feeling emotionally numb, dissociate from our surroundings, and feeling empty. 

When we are in the hypo-arousal or hyper-arousal states, our prefrontal cortex shuts down and we are outside our window of tolerance. This is important to understand because it allows us to recognize when we are not thinking and feeling our best, so we can take adequate steps to regulate ourselves. 

What state do you usually find yourself experiencing during extreme levels of stress? Hypo-arousal or Hyper-arousal?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nawal | M.A. Neuropsychology on June 21, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Boundaries are our own personal limits on how people can treat us, behave around us, and interact with us. 

We not only set boundaries with others, but also ourselves. We are human - we make mistakes, we can lash out, and/or disrespect others. Boundaries allow us to hold ourselves accountable and are essential for self-growth. 

Setting boundaries is not easy, especially if you never observed others setting and keeping boundaries around you. It can be difficult to identify where to start and what boundaries to set. 

So in this post, I wanted to simplify boundaries into five categories: Time, Communication, Mental, Emotional, and Physical. Swipe to see what each type of boundary might sound like. 

Which of these boundaries is the most difficult for you to set?
